jakarta-intercultural-school.name: Jakarta Intercultural School
jakarta-intercultural-school.addressFull: Pondok Indah Campus: Jl. Terogong Raya No. 33, Cilandak, Jakarta Selatan 12430; Pattimura Campus (Elementary): Jl. Pattimura Blok 1 No. 2, Kebayoran Baru, Jakarta Selatan 12110
jakarta-intercultural-school.nationalitiesDescription: Students from over 60 countries, with significant populations from the USA, South Korea, Japan, Australia, and Indonesia.
jakarta-intercultural-school.studentBodyDescription: JIS draws a mix of expatriate children and internationally-minded Indonesian families. The student body includes children of diplomats, multinational executives, and entrepreneurs. Many students have lived in multiple countries. Indonesian students now represent about 25% of enrolment, with the remainder spread across 60+ nationalities, the largest groups being American, South Korean, Japanese, and Australian.
jakarta-intercultural-school.curriculum: IB Primary Years | IB Middle Years | IB Diploma | AP
jakarta-intercultural-school.headBio: Dr. Tarek Razik has led JIS since 2022. He holds a doctorate in Educational Leadership from Columbia University and has over 25 years of experience in international schools, including previous headships in the Middle East and Africa.
jakarta-intercultural-school.academicDescription: JIS offers the full IB continuum from PYP through DP, alongside Advanced Placement courses for students preferring the American pathway. The IB Diploma average was 35.8 in 2024 with a pass rate above 97%. University destinations include US institutions (40-50% of graduates, including Ivy League and top-20), UK universities (around 25%, including Oxbridge and Russell Group), and growing numbers to Australia, Canada, and Europe. The middle school follows a modified IB MYP with American curriculum elements. Class sizes average 18-20 students. Learning support and EAL programmes are available. STEAM subjects are well-resourced with dedicated labs and maker spaces.
jakarta-intercultural-school.facilities: 50-meter Olympic swimming pool | Performing Arts Center with 800-seat auditorium | Three gymnasiums | Two libraries totaling 50,000 volumes | Dedicated elementary and secondary science labs | Design technology and robotics labs | Art studios and ceramics workshop | Tennis courts and multipurpose fields | Black box theater | Recording studio and music practice rooms | Two cafeterias with international cuisine
jakarta-intercultural-school.schoolLifeDescription: JIS runs a house system across grade levels with inter-house competitions in sports, arts, and community service. 'JIS Week' in February is the main cultural event, featuring performances, food fairs, and cultural presentations reflecting the school's international mix. The school competes in IASAS (Interscholastic Association of Southeast Asian Schools) against six other leading international schools across the region, and sport is a significant part of secondary school life. The arts programme produces large-scale musicals annually and there are dedicated music, drama, and visual arts spaces. Service learning is embedded into the curriculum. The Cilandak campus has a community feel, and many families use the pool and sports facilities at weekends. The PTA is active and well-organised.
jakarta-intercultural-school.intelligenceSummary:
The word among expat families is that JIS is the big, established name - the school most corporate packages are written around and the one relocation agents mention first. Founded in 1951, it has the history, the scale, and the resources that come with being Jakarta's largest international school. Parents describe it as offering an American-influenced education with a broad international mix of students. The main Cilandak campus runs Early Childhood through High School, while Pattimura in Kebayoran Baru takes Elementary (K-5).

Families who've been here a few years tend to say the strengths are real - strong university placements, a huge range of activities, and a community that feels like a small town. The flip side is that it's expensive (the most expensive in Jakarta), the campus is ageing, and at 2,500+ students it can feel impersonal if your child isn't the type to put their hand up. It suits families who want breadth of opportunity and don't mind a bigger, busier environment.

The general consensus: if your company is paying and your child is reasonably outgoing, JIS is a safe and solid choice. If you're self-funding or want a smaller, more personal setup, it's worth looking at what else is out there.
jakarta-intercultural-school.intelligencePositives: Strong university placement track record - graduates regularly go on to well-known US, UK, and Australian universities, with a solid Ivy League and Oxbridge pipeline. Parents say the college counselling team is experienced and well-connected. | Diverse student body with 60+ nationalities and no single group dominating - parents value the fact that their children mix with families from all over the world rather than one or two dominant communities. | Serious sports programme through IASAS, competing against top international schools across Southeast Asia. Good range of team and individual sports, and high participation rates across the secondary school. | Large-scale arts and performing arts programme - annual musicals, orchestra, and dedicated performance spaces mean students who are into drama, music, or visual arts have real outlets and resources. | Well-established alumni network going back over 70 years - useful for older students thinking about university applications, internships, and career connections.
jakarta-intercultural-school.intelligenceConsiderations: At IDR 527M+ per year rising to IDR 604M for IB, JIS is comfortably the most expensive school in Jakarta. The gap between JIS and the next tier down is significant - make sure you're clear on what the premium buys you before committing. | The Cilandak campus dates from the mid-1970s and parts of it are showing their age. A renovation programme is underway but it's a big site and there's still plenty of work to do. Don't expect gleaming, purpose-built facilities throughout. | Traffic around the Cilandak campus at drop-off is a genuine headache. Jl. Terogong Raya backs up badly between 7:15 and 7:45 AM. Families who live in BSD or Tangerang should factor in a long commute. | With 2,500+ students, JIS is a big school. Parents of quieter children sometimes say their kids can get lost in the crowd, particularly in middle school. It works well for confident, outgoing students - less so for those who need to be drawn out. | The American-influenced approach - first-name basis with teachers, emphasis on student voice and choice - suits some families but feels too informal for those coming from British or more traditional Asian school cultures.
jakarta-intercultural-school.inspectionFindings: CIS/WASC joint accreditation review noted strong student learning outcomes and community engagement. The report highlighted the school's mission-driven approach and breadth of programme offerings.
jakarta-intercultural-school.verifiedContent: Jakarta Intercultural School is a non-profit, co-educational international school established in 1951. The school is accredited by the Council of International Schools and the Western Association of Schools and Colleges.
jakarta-intercultural-school.parentSummary: Jakarta's largest and most expensive international school. Strong IB results (avg 35.8), huge campus, 60+ nationalities. Suits corporate-package families.

british-school-jakarta.name: British School Jakarta
british-school-jakarta.addressFull: Bintaro Jaya Sektor 9, Jl. Raya Jombang, Pondok Aren, Tangerang Selatan 15427, Indonesia
british-school-jakarta.nationalitiesDescription: Students from over 50 countries, with British, Indonesian, Korean, and Australian families among the largest groups.
british-school-jakarta.studentBodyDescription: BSJ's student body includes children of diplomats, business executives, and Indonesian families. British families make up the largest single group, followed by Indonesian, Korean, and Australian students. Most classrooms have 15 or more nationalities represented.
british-school-jakarta.academicDescription: BSJ follows the British Curriculum from Early Years through IGCSEs (Year 11), then offers the IB Diploma in Years 12-13. The IB average sits around 35 with a pass rate near 98%. University counselling begins in Year 9, with graduates going on to UK, US, Australian, and European universities.
british-school-jakarta.facilities: 45-acre campus | 50-metre swimming pool | Sports fields and courts | Performing arts centre | Science laboratories | Design technology workshops | Libraries | Art studios | Music practice rooms | Multiple cafeterias
british-school-jakarta.schoolLifeDescription: BSJ offers over 260 extracurricular activities including sports, arts, community service, and academic clubs. A house system runs across year groups. The school has a partnership with Manchester City Football Club for its football programme. Annual events include sports days, arts festivals, and cultural celebrations.
british-school-jakarta.intelligenceSummary:
The word among expat families is that BSJ is the established British option in Jakarta, sitting alongside JIS and ISJ as one of the top-tier international schools. The 45-acre Bintaro campus is one of the largest school sites in Indonesia, and the British curriculum through to IB Diploma is a well-trodden path. Parents describe a school that feels structured and traditional, with a strong sense of community.

The main trade-off is location. Bintaro is a fair distance from central Jakarta, and families who don't live nearby face a significant commute. The British culture runs deep (house system, prefects, cricket), which suits some families and feels unfamiliar to others. Academically, IB results are solid, and the breadth of activities is notable for Jakarta.
british-school-jakarta.intelligencePositives: Large 45-acre campus with extensive sports facilities including a 50-metre pool, multiple football pitches, tennis courts, and an athletics track. One of the biggest school campuses in Indonesia. | IB results are solid, with an average around 35 and a pass rate near 98%. Graduates go on to well-known universities in the UK, US, Australia, and elsewhere. | Manchester City FC partnership brings professional football coaching to campus. Student participation in the football programme is high. | Over 260 co-curricular activities with high participation rates. The Duke of Edinburgh programme and debate team are popular options. | Founded in 1974, BSJ has a long-established alumni network. It was the first British school in Indonesia and has deep roots in the expat community.
british-school-jakarta.intelligenceConsiderations: Bintaro is about 22km from central Jakarta. Morning commute can be 35-45 minutes via the JORR toll road, or over an hour in heavy traffic. Most BSJ families live nearby in Bintaro or BSD. | The school follows the British National Curriculum through IGCSE, then switches to IB at Year 12. Families wanting IB from primary age may prefer a full-continuum IB school. | Bus routes from central Jakarta can mean early mornings. The longest routes take over an hour, with pickups starting around 6:30 AM. | The culture is distinctly British, with a house system, prefects, formal assemblies, and sports like rugby and cricket. This suits some families and feels unfamiliar to others. | The student body leans British in character, which is a draw for some families and a limitation for those seeking a more internationally blended environment.
british-school-jakarta.verifiedContent: British School Jakarta is an international school offering British curriculum education for students aged 2-18. The school is accredited by CIS, COBIS, and BSO.
british-school-jakarta.parentSummary: Jakarta's established British school. Dual British/IB pathway, large Bintaro campus, strong IB results (avg 35). Far from central Jakarta.

independent-school-of-jakarta.name: The Independent School of Jakarta
independent-school-of-jakarta.addressFull: Jl. R.A. Kartini No.Kav. 12, Pondok Pinang, Kebayoran Lama, South Jakarta 12310, Indonesia
independent-school-of-jakarta.nationalitiesDescription: Students from over 30 nationalities, creating a diverse international community.
independent-school-of-jakarta.studentBodyDescription: ISJ serves families from over 30 nationalities, with children aged 2 to 13 across Pre-Prep (ages 2-6) and Prep School (ages 7-13). The school is expanding year groups progressively. The mix includes expatriate families seeking continuity with UK education standards and Indonesian families drawn to the British independent school model.
independent-school-of-jakarta.accreditation: COBIS | BSO | IAPS | The Schools Trust | IGCSEs | Pearson Edexcel | Indonesian Ministry of Education
independent-school-of-jakarta.headBio: Eileen Fisher has led preparatory schools in the UK and internationally, including roles within the Girls' Day School Trust network and The British School of Cairo. She is also an experienced school inspector.
independent-school-of-jakarta.academicDescription: ISJ follows the British Curriculum, supplemented with IGCSEs and Pearson Edexcel qualifications. Class sizes are small with a focus on personalised attention. The curriculum covers English, Mathematics, Science, Humanities, Languages, Computing, Art, Music, Drama, and Physical Education.
independent-school-of-jakarta.facilities: Swimming pool | Football pitch | Playground | Science and technology labs | Performance and art spaces | Outdoor sports areas | Classrooms | Green grounds
independent-school-of-jakarta.schoolLifeDescription: Pupils take part in sports, creative arts, performances, clubs, and outdoor learning alongside academics. The school places emphasis on character development and leadership opportunities. The small community means staff know every child individually.
independent-school-of-jakarta.intelligenceSummary:
Parents describe ISJ as the small, personal British option in Jakarta's international school landscape. Part of The Schools Trust network, it serves around 200 children aged 2 to 13 in the Pondok Pinang area, with year groups expanding progressively. The teaching staff are recruited from well-regarded UK schools, and with class sizes capped at 16, the level of individual attention is a genuine differentiator from larger schools like JIS and BSJ.

The trade-off is clear: ISJ doesn't yet run through to Year 13, so families need to plan a transition to a senior school. The smaller scale also means fewer activities and a narrower peer group. For families who prioritise a British prep school feel with close teacher-student relationships, it's a strong fit. For those wanting a full K-12 journey or a wide menu of extracurriculars, the bigger schools may suit better.
independent-school-of-jakarta.intelligencePositives: Teaching staff are recruited from well-regarded UK independent schools and most have significant classroom experience. The school maintains small class sizes of up to 16 students. | With around 200 students, every child is known by name. Parents report strong communication from teachers and easy access to the head. | The school is expanding year groups progressively, adding one new year group per year. Early families have had input into shaping school culture. | Holds accreditation from COBIS, BSO, IAPS, and The Schools Trust, which is a broad set of endorsements for a school of this size. | Graduates have moved on to senior schools including BSJ, JIS, Harrow Bangkok, and UK boarding schools. The school provides dedicated placement support from Year 6.
independent-school-of-jakarta.intelligenceConsiderations: Currently serves ages 2 to 13 only. Families need to plan a transition to a senior school, which adds complexity compared to K-12 options. | The smaller scale means fewer co-curricular activities than larger schools. The range is narrower, though participation rates are high. | Founded in 2018, so it is still a relatively young school without a long track record or established alumni network. | Exclusively British curriculum. Families wanting IB, American AP, or bilingual Mandarin programmes will need to look elsewhere. | Fees are positioned between local private schools and the top-tier internationals. Whether that represents value depends on what you prioritise.
independent-school-of-jakarta.verifiedContent: The Independent School of Jakarta is a British international school for children aged 2 to 13, located in Pondok Indah, South Jakarta. The school is part of The Schools Trust and offers the British Curriculum with IGCSEs and Pearson Edexcel qualifications.
independent-school-of-jakarta.parentSummary: Small, personal British school. Pastoral care standout, class sizes capped at 16. Primary only - no secondary yet.

sinarmas-world-academy.name: Sinarmas World Academy
sinarmas-world-academy.addressFull: CBD Lot XV, Jl. BSD Grand Boulevard, BSD City, Tangerang 15339, Indonesia
sinarmas-world-academy.nationalitiesDescription: Students from over 40 nationalities, with Indonesian families making up the majority alongside Korean, Chinese, and Japanese students.
sinarmas-world-academy.studentBodyDescription: SWA's student body is predominantly Indonesian, with Korean, Chinese, and Japanese families forming the next largest groups. The school attracts academically focused families. English is the primary language of instruction, with Mandarin offered as a second language.
sinarmas-world-academy.curriculum: British Curriculum | IB Middle Years | IB Diploma
sinarmas-world-academy.academicDescription: SWA offers the UK Early Years Foundation Stage curriculum, British Curriculum for elementary and middle school integrated with IB Middle Years, and the IB Diploma. The IB average is 38.2 with a 99% pass rate. The BEST (Business, Engineering, Science, Technology) streaming programme from Grade 9 allows students to focus on a career pathway. Graduates go on to well-known universities in the US, UK, Australia, and Asia.
sinarmas-world-academy.facilities: Purpose-built campus | Science and technology labs | Design studios | Performing arts centre | Sports facilities | Swimming pool | Libraries | Maker spaces
sinarmas-world-academy.schoolLifeDescription: SWA has a strong robotics programme and has competed at the World Robot Olympiad. Service learning and sustainability initiatives are part of the curriculum. The school has exchange partnerships with institutions in China, Korea, and Japan.
sinarmas-world-academy.intelligenceSummary:
Newcomers are usually told that SWA is the school for families who prioritise IB results above most other factors. The numbers back this up: with an IB average around 38, it is one of the highest-performing IB schools in Southeast Asia. The school has a strong STEM orientation and its robotics teams have competed internationally.

The trade-off is that the academic culture is intense. Homework loads are heavy by high school, and the environment suits students who thrive under high expectations. The BSD City location is also a significant commute from central and south Jakarta, though many SWA families choose to live nearby.
sinarmas-world-academy.intelligencePositives: IB results are among the highest in Indonesia, with an average around 38 and a pass rate near 99%. A meaningful number of students score 40 or above. | Strong STEM programme with notable success in robotics competitions, including multiple medals at the World Robot Olympiad. Many graduates go on to pursue STEM degrees. | Purpose-built campus with specialised science labs, maker spaces, and collaborative learning areas. The facilities are well-suited to the school's academic focus. | The BEST streaming programme from Grade 9 lets students focus on Business, Engineering, Science, or Technology, with industry mentorship and internship opportunities. | University counselling starts from Grade 9, and graduates are placed at well-known universities in the US, UK, and across Asia.

This suits high-achieving students but may not be the right fit for every child. | The student body is predominantly Indonesian and Asian. Families looking for a more Western-oriented or internationally blended environment may find the mix different from schools like JIS or BSJ. | Founded in 2008, SWA is a younger school compared to JIS or BSJ. The alumni network is still developing. | Admissions are selective, with entrance examinations. Families prioritising a more holistic or relaxed approach may prefer other options.
sinarmas-world-academy.verifiedContent: Sinarmas World Academy opened in 2008 and offers the IB Diploma with one of the highest averages globally. The school is authorized by the IB and accredited by CIS.
sinarmas-world-academy.parentSummary: Jakarta's top IB results school (avg 37+). Academically rigorous, BSD campus, attracts achievement-focused families. Premium fees.

australian-independent-school-jakarta.name: Australian Independent School Jakarta
australian-independent-school-jakarta.addressFull: Jl. Pejaten Barat No. 68, Kemang, Jakarta Selatan 12550, Indonesia
australian-independent-school-jakarta.nationalitiesDescription: Students from over 40 nationalities, with the largest groups being Australian, Indonesian, and British/European.
australian-independent-school-jakarta.studentBodyDescription: AIS Jakarta attracts families seeking the Australian education approach. The student body is around 30% Australian, 25% Indonesian, and 15% British/European. Many families are planning to move to Australia, are on rotation, or appreciate the Australian curriculum's focus on inquiry-based learning and wellbeing. The school also has a campus in Bali.
australian-independent-school-jakarta.academicDescription: AIS Jakarta follows the Australian Curriculum from Preschool through Year 10, with the IB Diploma offered for Years 11-12. The curriculum emphasizes inquiry-based learning, critical thinking, and holistic development. University placements include Australian, Asian, European, and North American institutions.
australian-independent-school-jakarta.facilities: Campus in Pejaten | Science laboratories | Library | Sports facilities | Art studios | Music rooms | Outdoor areas | 25-metre pool | Indoor gymnasium | Performing arts studio
australian-independent-school-jakarta.schoolLifeDescription: Life at AIS Jakarta reflects Australian educational values of wellbeing, inclusion, and inquiry. The school offers extracurricular activities including sports, arts, and community service. The approach creates a supportive environment for students to take academic risks and develop confidence.
australian-independent-school-jakarta.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say AIS is where you go if your family has ties to Australia or you simply want a less pressured, wellbeing-focused school. It is the only school in Jakarta offering the full Australian Curriculum, which means seamless transfers to and from Australia for families on rotation. The IB Diploma is available for Years 11-12. The Pejaten campus is convenient for the Kemang expat community.

The trade-off is that the Australian Curriculum is less universally recognised by US and UK universities than the IB alone, and the campus is more compact than the big suburban schools. For families who value wellbeing over academic intensity, and especially those with Australian connections, AIS is a well-regarded choice.
australian-independent-school-jakarta.intelligencePositives: Jakarta's only school offering the complete Australian Curriculum (ACARA) from Preschool through Year 10. This suits some families but means fewer activity options and peer groups. | AIS emphasises wellbeing and character development over academic pressure. Families specifically seeking British or American pathways have other options.
australian-independent-school-jakarta.verifiedContent: Australian Independent School Jakarta offers the Australian Curriculum and IB Diploma for students aged 3-18. The school is accredited by CIS and is an IB World School.

tunas-muda-school.name: Tunas Muda School
tunas-muda-school.addressFull: Meruya Campus: Jl. Meruya Utara Raya No.71, Kembangan, Jakarta Barat 11620; Kedoya Campus: Jl. Angsana Raya D8/2, Kedoya, Jakarta Barat 11520
tunas-muda-school.nationalitiesDescription: Students from 20+ nationalities in a Catholic international community.
tunas-muda-school.studentBodyDescription: Students from 20+ nationalities in a Catholic international community. The school serves the West Jakarta area with two campuses, drawing families who want an IB education with a faith-based foundation.
tunas-muda-school.curriculum: IB Primary Years | IB Middle Years | IB Diploma
tunas-muda-school.academicDescription: Tunas Muda offers the complete IB continuum from PYP through MYP to Diploma Programme. Founded in 1994, the school has over 25 years of IB experience. English is the primary language of instruction with Indonesian and other languages offered.
tunas-muda-school.facilities: Two West Jakarta campuses | Science laboratories | Libraries | Sports facilities | Chapel | Arts studios | Music rooms
tunas-muda-school.schoolLifeDescription: School life integrates IB inquiry-based learning with Catholic faith development. Students participate in CAS (Creativity, Activity, Service), religious formation, and character development. The two-campus setup creates connections between families in the West Jakarta area.
tunas-muda-school.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say Tunas Muda is one of the few schools in Jakarta offering the complete IB continuum - PYP, MYP, and Diploma - with genuine Catholic values woven throughout. Founded in 1994, it has over 25 years of IB experience, which gives it a depth that newer IB schools lack.

The word among families is that the school has a warm, close-knit feel. Two West Jakarta campuses serve the Kembangan area, which is convenient for local families but less so for those in South or East Jakarta. Catholic formation is central to the community, not just a formality.

For Catholic families in West Jakarta who want the IB pathway, Tunas Muda is a natural fit. Families should be aware that fees sit at the mid-to-upper range for Jakarta IB schools, and the smaller size means fewer extracurricular options compared to the big three (JIS, BSJ, ISJ).
tunas-muda-school.intelligencePositives: Complete IB continuum (PYP, MYP, DP) with over 25 years of delivery experience. | Catholic values are genuinely integrated throughout the IB programmes. | Two West Jakarta campus locations are convenient for families in the area. | WASC accreditation alongside IBO provides additional quality assurance.
tunas-muda-school.intelligenceConsiderations: West Jakarta locations are less convenient for South or East Jakarta families. | Catholic ethos is central to school life and may not suit all families. | Fees sit at the mid-to-upper range for Jakarta IB schools. | Smaller school size means fewer extracurricular options than larger institutions. | Lower international profile compared to leading schools like JIS, BSJ, and ISJ.
tunas-muda-school.verifiedContent: Tunas Muda School is an IB World School offering PYP, MYP, and Diploma Programme with Catholic values across two West Jakarta campuses.
tunas-muda-school.parentSummary: Parents say Tunas Muda is one of the few schools in Jakarta offering the complete IB continuum - PYP, MYP, and Diplom...

btb-school.name: BTB School
btb-school.addressFull: Jl. Pluit Timur Blok MM, RW.4, Pluit, Kec. Penjaringan, Jakarta Utara 14450, Indonesia
btb-school.nationalitiesDescription: Around 20 nationalities with a significant proportion of Indonesian-Chinese families alongside Korean, Japanese, and other Asian nationalities.
btb-school.studentBodyDescription: BTB draws primarily from the North Jakarta Chinese-Indonesian community, with a growing number of expatriate families from across Asia. The school has a strong bilingual identity with English as the primary language of instruction and Mandarin as a key second language. Many families value the combination of IB and Cambridge qualifications.
btb-school.curriculum: IB Primary Years | IGCSEs | IB Diploma
btb-school.academicDescription: BTB offers IB PYP in primary school, IGCSEs at secondary level, and the IB Diploma in senior years. This dual-pathway approach gives students both Cambridge and IB qualifications. Mandarin language is a significant part of the programme. The school has been an IB World School since 2005. University placements include destinations in Australia, the UK, the US, and across Asia.
btb-school.facilities: Swimming pool | Basketball courts | Science laboratories | Library | Music rooms | Art studios | IT labs | Auditorium | Canteen | Sports hall
btb-school.schoolLifeDescription: BTB has a North Jakarta community feel with strong connections to the Pluit area. The school runs a range of co-curricular activities including sports, arts, and academic clubs. Chinese cultural traditions are celebrated alongside international events. The school participates in inter-school competitions and community service projects.
btb-school.intelligenceSummary:
BTB School (formerly Bina Tunas Bangsa) is a well-established IB World School in Pluit, North Jakarta, with a distinctive bilingual English-Mandarin identity. It's been running IB programmes since 2005, making it one of the more experienced IB schools in Jakarta.

The school is popular with Chinese-Indonesian families and the growing Korean and Japanese expat communities in North Jakarta. The combination of IB PYP, IGCSEs, and IB Diploma gives students flexibility - something parents appreciate.

Fees sit in the mid-to-upper range, starting around IDR 158M for early years and reaching IDR 415M for IB Diploma. For North Jakarta families, it's a strong option without the long commute south to JIS or BSJ.
btb-school.intelligencePositives: Dual qualification pathway combining IB and Cambridge - students get both IGCSE and IB Diploma options. | Strong Mandarin language programme alongside English-medium instruction. | IB World School since 2005 - well-established experience with the IB framework. | North Jakarta location convenient for families in Pluit, Kelapa Gading, and Pantai Indah Kapuk areas. | Growing international diversity beyond its traditional Chinese-Indonesian base.
btb-school.intelligenceConsiderations: Predominantly Chinese-Indonesian student body - less internationally diverse than JIS or BSJ. | North Jakarta location means long commutes for families in the south or west of the city. | Campus facilities are solid but more compact than the premium-tier schools. | Less visibility for UK/US university placements compared to bigger-name schools. | Mandarin emphasis is a strength for some families but may not suit those wanting a purely English-medium environment.
btb-school.verifiedContent: BTB School is an IB World School in North Jakarta offering IB PYP, IGCSEs, and IB Diploma programmes. Authorised as an IB school since September 2005.

sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.name: Sekolah Pelita Harapan Kemang Village
sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.addressFull: Jl. Pangeran Antasari No. 36, Cipete Selatan, Jakarta Selatan 12150, Indonesia
sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.nationalitiesDescription: Student body is predominantly Indonesian with international families from around 30 countries.
sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.studentBodyDescription: SPH Kemang attracts families seeking a Christian-based international education. The student body includes Indonesian families who value faith-integrated learning alongside expatriate families. The mix is around 55% Indonesian, with Korean, Australian, and Western European families making up much of the remainder.
sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.academicDescription: SPH offers a Christian worldview-integrated curriculum with IGCSEs and IB Diploma qualifications. The school emphasizes holistic education. The Advanced Science Academy programme offers research opportunities for academically strong students. University placements span Indonesia, Australia, the US, UK, and Asia.
sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.facilities: Campus in Kemang area | Science laboratories | Sports facilities | Performing arts spaces | Library | Chapel | Indoor gymnasium | 25-metre pool
sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.schoolLifeDescription: SPH life is centred on faith, learning, and community service. The Mission Service Learning programme engages students in local and regional service projects. Arts and sports programmes complement academics. Chapel services and Christian values are integrated throughout school life. The parent community is active.
sekolah-pelita-harapan-kemang-village.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say SPH Kemang is the school for families who want strong academics with a genuine Christian foundation. It is the most centrally located campus of SPH's five-campus network, and the Kemang Village location works well for South Jakarta families. The Christian ethos is not a side note here - chapel, Bible integration, and service are woven through daily life.

The word among expat families is that SPH offers solid IB and Cambridge qualifications at fees well below JIS or BSJ. The trade-off is that the campus is compact and urban, the student body leans heavily Indonesian, and families need to be genuinely comfortable with the faith-based approach. For those who are, it is a well-regarded option with a long track record.

The Nord Anglia network gives families access to MIT and Juilliard-linked programmes, plus easy transfers if you move to another city with a Nord Anglia school. The key thing to know is that NAS only goes up to Year 6, so every family will need to find a secondary school. For families who are internationally mobile or specifically want a focused British primary experience, this works well. If you want K-12 continuity on one campus, look elsewhere.

Fees are estimated in the mid-range bracket, with upper levels reaching around IDR 280-338M. The school is smaller and more personal than the big international schools, which suits families looking for closer teacher-student relationships.

The trade-off is limited international diversity, fewer facilities, and lower visibility for university placements. For families who want Cambridge qualifications in a faith-based environment at a mid-range price point, it's worth a visit.

IPEKA Integrated Christian School offers Australian Curriculum K-9 with IB Diploma for senior years - a less common combination in Jakarta. Triple accreditation (WASC, ACSI, IBO) gives it international recognition, and the trilingual instruction in English, Mandarin, and Indonesian is a draw.

The trade-off is location - the West Jakarta campus is less convenient for South Jakarta families. The Australian Curriculum is also less familiar to many Jakarta expats than Cambridge or IB, and the transition from Australian to IB in the senior years requires adjustment. Fee information is not publicly disclosed.

Parents say ACS Jakarta is a well-regarded option for families who want the structure and discipline of a Singapore-heritage school with internationally recognised qualifications. The word among families is that the 8-hectare East Jakarta campus is spacious with good facilities, but the Cipayung location is a real consideration - it is 28km from Kemang and most families choose housing in East Jakarta or Bekasi to keep commutes manageable. Methodist values are woven through school life, so families should be comfortable with that ethos.

For families who value structured academics and are based in East Jakarta, ACS is a serious contender. Early bird and sibling discounts plus merit scholarships can bring the effective cost down. Families preferring inquiry-based learning from the start may find the approach more exam-focused than expected.

The word among families is that the school does what it sets out to do very well: Korean curriculum, Korean-language instruction, and a strong Korean community. For Korean expatriate families and Korean-heritage Indonesians, JIKS is the primary option in Jakarta. Non-Korean families should only consider it if they are comfortable with Korean-language instruction and the Korean educational approach.

cikal-school.intelligenceSummary:
The word among progressive Jakarta families is that Cikal is the school doing things differently. Founded in 1999, it pioneered competency-based, personalised learning in Indonesia and became an IB World School in 2015. It has campuses in Lebak Bulus, Serpong, Amri Setu, and Kemang, each with its own community feel.

Parents say the inclusive education programme and the 5 Stars Competencies framework are genuine strengths - not just marketing. The no-uniform policy signals the school's progressive ethos. The trade-off is that the Cikal curriculum is less standardised than pure IB or Cambridge pathways, and the school is less well-known internationally for university placements. The student body is predominantly Indonesian.

The full IB continuum and WASC accreditation give it solid credentials, and the Kelapa Gading location is a genuine advantage for families in that part of the city.

The word among families is that the community is warm and close-knit - the smaller size means staff know students and parents by name. The trade-off is that it does not have the same resources or name recognition as the larger South Jakarta schools, and the range of activities and peer groups is naturally more limited.

For North Jakarta families, NJIS offers a well-regarded IB pathway at fees that sit in the upper-mid range. The 5% sibling discount is a nice touch for families with multiple children. Families in South or Central Jakarta should factor in the commute before committing.

Founded in 1998, it has built a steady reputation in West Jakarta.

The campuses in Permata Buana and Cibubur work for families on that side of the city, but South Jakarta families will find the commute long. The school appeals to families who want structure, values-based education, and bilingual English-Mandarin instruction. It is less internationally diverse than the big-name schools, and the Christian ethos is central to school life.

The word among families is that the Jakarta Garden City campus is well-maintained and the Singapore curriculum foundation is solid, particularly in maths. However, the school is still building its track record compared to longer-established names, and IB results are not widely published.

Newcomers from German-speaking countries are usually told about DSJ early on. It is the main German curriculum school in Jakarta, subsidised by the German government, so fees are well below what most international schools charge. The BSD City campus is well-equipped, and the Abitur is a respected qualification for European university entry.

For non-German speakers, the International Programme provides an English-medium option following German standards. The trade-off is location - BSD City is a long way from central or east Jakarta. And if your university targets are mainly in the US or UK, the Abitur is less familiar to admissions offices there than the IB or A-Levels.

It is not a mainstream choice among expat families, but Indonesian parents seeking an active-learning, research-backed methodology combined with national curriculum integration find it appealing. The TB Simatupang main campus is WASC accredited.

The practical advantage is multiple campuses across Jakarta (TB Simatupang, Kelapa Gading, Kuningan, Pluit), so you can usually find one near you. The trade-off is that the HighScope Curriculum is not well-known internationally, and there are no IB or Cambridge qualifications at secondary level, which may limit options for university applications abroad.

The two Tangerang campuses are spacious and well-maintained, though the location rules it out for families based in central or east Jakarta.

For Catholic families in the Tangerang corridor who want bilingual education with international credentials at accessible fees, Santa Laurensia is a strong contender. Families unfamiliar with Pearson Edexcel should research how the qualification is recognised by their target universities.

sekolah-madania.name: Sekolah Madania
sekolah-madania.addressFull: Jl. Raya Parung Km. 7, Telaga Kahuripan, Parung, Bogor 16310, Indonesia
sekolah-madania.nationalitiesDescription: Indonesian and international students seeking inclusive international education.
sekolah-madania.studentBodyDescription: Indonesian and international students, with around 15 nationalities represented. The school offers both day and boarding options, attracting families from a wider catchment than Bogor alone. The inclusive education approach accommodates students with diverse learning needs.
sekolah-madania.curriculum: IB Primary Years | IGCSEs | Indonesian National Curriculum
sekolah-madania.academicDescription: IB PYP for primary years and IGCSEs for secondary, alongside Indonesian National Curriculum. Bilingual English-Indonesian instruction throughout. The school accommodates diverse learning needs through its inclusive education approach. No IB Diploma pathway is currently available for senior years. No published exam results data.
sekolah-madania.facilities: Bogor campus with open grounds | Boarding facilities | Science laboratories | Libraries | Sports facilities | Arts studios
sekolah-madania.schoolLifeDescription: Day and boarding students share the campus. Students participate in outdoor education and community service. The Bogor location provides more open space than most Jakarta-based schools.
sekolah-madania.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say Sekolah Madania is the choice for families who want a more spacious, inclusive school environment away from Jakarta's congestion. The word among families is that the school genuinely accommodates different learning needs - not just on paper, but in practice. The boarding option extends its reach beyond Bogor families.

The trade-off is that the Bogor location means a significant commute from Jakarta, and traffic can make this unpredictable. There is no IB Diploma pathway, so families planning for senior years will need to consider a transition.

For families who value inclusive education, green space, and a less pressured environment, Madania offers something different from the Jakarta mainstream.

sekolah-pelita-bangsa.name: Sekolah Pelita Bangsa
sekolah-pelita-bangsa.addressFull: Jl. Perumahan Citra 5 No.1 Blok A.5, Kalideres, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
sekolah-pelita-bangsa.nationalitiesDescription: Predominantly Indonesian families in the Citra/Kalideres area seeking Cambridge education.
sekolah-pelita-bangsa.studentBodyDescription: Predominantly Indonesian families in the Citra/Kalideres area of West Jakarta. Around 10 nationalities represented. The school has grown steadily since its founding in 2003 and draws families seeking Cambridge qualifications at a lower price point than the larger international schools.
sekolah-pelita-bangsa.curriculum: Cambridge Primary | IGCSEs | Indonesian National Curriculum
sekolah-pelita-bangsa.academicDescription: Cambridge curriculum from early years through secondary. Founded in 2003. The school focuses on Cambridge examination preparation with character development alongside academics. No IB or A-Level pathway available.
sekolah-pelita-bangsa.schoolLifeDescription: The school focuses on academic development alongside character education. Students participate in co-curricular programmes. The community is close-knit given the smaller student body.
sekolah-pelita-bangsa.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say Pelita Bangsa is a practical option for West Jakarta families who want Cambridge qualifications without the fees of the bigger international schools. Established in 2003, it has built a steady reputation in the Citra/Kalideres area.

The word among families is that the school does what it sets out to do - deliver Cambridge curriculum at an accessible price. Class sizes are smaller, and the community feel is a draw for families who want their children known by name. The trade-off is fewer resources and activities compared to larger schools.

For families in West Jakarta who are self-funding and want internationally recognised qualifications, Pelita Bangsa is worth a look. Families in South Jakarta will find the commute a challenge.

millennia-world-school.name: Millennia World School
millennia-world-school.addressFull: Jl. Merpati Raya No.103, Sawah Lama, Ciputat, Tangerang Selatan, Banten, Indonesia
millennia-world-school.nationalitiesDescription: Predominantly Indonesian families seeking alternative education approaches.
millennia-world-school.studentBodyDescription: Predominantly Indonesian families seeking an alternative to conventional schooling. International diversity is limited. Parents tend to share an interest in holistic, arts-integrated education.
millennia-world-school.curriculum: Finnish Waldorf Framework | Indonesian National Curriculum
millennia-world-school.academicDescription: Millennia World School follows a Finnish Waldorf framework integrated with the Indonesian National Curriculum, operating since 2017. The approach is experiential, with arts, music, and movement woven into daily learning. There are no internationally recognised qualifications such as Cambridge or IB. The school currently runs through Junior High School only.
millennia-world-school.facilities: Ciputat campus | Arts studios | Music rooms | Outdoor learning spaces | Gardens | Movement spaces
millennia-world-school.schoolLifeDescription: Daily life follows Waldorf philosophy with arts, crafts, music, and movement integrated into the curriculum. There is no uniform. The emphasis is on creativity and hands-on learning rather than testing and examinations.
millennia-world-school.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say Millennia World School is one of the few genuine alternatives to test-driven education in Greater Jakarta. The Finnish Waldorf approach - hands-on, arts-rich, and deliberately unhurried - appeals to families who feel their children would not flourish in a conventional academic setting. Founded in 2017 in Ciputat, the school is still relatively young.

The word among families is that children are happy here and the creative emphasis is real, not just marketing. The trade-off is clear: there are no internationally recognised qualifications, and the school only goes through Junior High School, so families need a plan for senior secondary.

For families in the Tangerang Selatan area who value holistic development over exam results, it is a distinctive option. Those who need a clear academic pathway to university should weigh the lack of Cambridge or IB credentials carefully.

sekolah-cita-buana.addressFull: Jl. Paso No.84, Jagakarsa, Jakarta Selatan 12620, Indonesia

sekolah-cita-buana.studentBodyDescription: Predominantly Indonesian families from the Jagakarsa and wider South Jakarta area. The school is known for enrolling students with diverse learning needs alongside mainstream students. International diversity is limited.
sekolah-cita-buana.curriculum: International Primary Curriculum | Cambridge Primary | Indonesian National Curriculum
sekolah-cita-buana.academicDescription: Sekolah Cita Buana uses the International Primary Curriculum (IPC) enriched with Cambridge standards and Indonesian National Curriculum. Instruction is bilingual in English and Indonesian. The inclusive model supports students with diverse learning needs within mainstream classrooms. There is currently no IB or A-Level pathway for senior years.
sekolah-cita-buana.facilities: Jagakarsa campus | Science laboratories | Libraries | Sports facilities | Arts rooms | Learning support facilities
sekolah-cita-buana.schoolLifeDescription: The school practises inclusive education, with students of diverse learning needs supported alongside mainstream peers. School culture emphasises community and individual development. Co-curricular activities include arts, sports, and service projects.
sekolah-cita-buana.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say Sekolah Cita Buana stands out for its genuine commitment to inclusive education - it is one of the few schools in Jakarta that actively supports students with diverse learning needs in mainstream classrooms. The fees are among the lowest for any school offering international-standard curriculum, and flexible capital fee payment plans make it more accessible.

The word among families is that the bilingual IPC and Cambridge approach gives children decent English exposure without the price of premium international schools. The Jagakarsa campus is modest, and the school is smaller, which means fewer activities and a narrower peer group - but also a community where families know each other.

For South Jakarta families who value inclusion and affordability, it is a distinctive choice. Those who need IB or A-Level pathways for senior years, or who want a larger and more internationally diverse school, will need to consider other options.

labschool-jakarta.name: Labschool Jakarta
labschool-jakarta.addressFull: Jl. Pemuda, Rawamangun, Jakarta Timur, Indonesia
labschool-jakarta.nationalitiesDescription: Predominantly Indonesian students with some international representation.
labschool-jakarta.studentBodyDescription: Predominantly Indonesian students with limited international representation. Around 5 nationalities. Admissions are competitive, and the school draws academically motivated families from across Jakarta. Affiliated with Universitas Negeri Jakarta (UNJ).
labschool-jakarta.academicDescription: Indonesian National Curriculum enriched with IGCSEs and A-Levels for international pathways. As a laboratory school affiliated with UNJ, teaching methods are research-based. Science and mathematics are areas of emphasis. No IB Diploma pathway offered.
labschool-jakarta.facilities: Science laboratories | Libraries | Sports facilities | Auditorium | Computer labs
labschool-jakarta.schoolLifeDescription: The school emphasises academic focus, character development, and leadership. Students participate in co-curricular activities across sports, arts, and community service. The alumni network is active and supports university admissions and career connections.
labschool-jakarta.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say Labschool is one of the most well-known national-plus schools in Indonesia - the UNJ affiliation gives it academic credibility, and the IGCSE and A-Level options add an international dimension that most national schools lack. Admissions are competitive, and families describe the academic culture as rigorous and structured.

The word among families is that the school produces strong results within the Indonesian system, and the alumni network is a genuine asset for university pathways. The trade-off is that it is primarily a national school - the student body is almost entirely Indonesian, and the approach is quite different from a full international school.

For Indonesian families wanting a well-regarded national education with Cambridge options, Labschool is a solid choice. Expat families or those seeking a fully international environment will likely find it a mismatch.

sekolah-victory-plus.name: Sekolah Victory Plus
sekolah-victory-plus.addressFull: Jl. Citra Niaga Raya Blok AO 1-14, Perumahan Kemang Pratama, Bekasi 17116, Indonesia
sekolah-victory-plus.nationalitiesDescription: Students from 20+ nationalities in the growing Bekasi international community.
sekolah-victory-plus.studentBodyDescription: Students from around 20 nationalities, drawn primarily from the Bekasi and East Jakarta area. The community includes both Indonesian families and a smaller expat population. The Early Years programme accepts children from 6 months.
sekolah-victory-plus.curriculum: IB Primary Years | IB Middle Years | IB Diploma
sekolah-victory-plus.academicDescription: Sekolah Victory Plus is an authorised IB Continuum school offering PYP, MYP, and Diploma Programme. Fees are significantly lower than most Jakarta IB schools. The approach is inquiry-based and experiential across all three programmes.
sekolah-victory-plus.facilities: Kemang Pratama campus | Science laboratories | Libraries | Sports facilities | Early years centre
sekolah-victory-plus.schoolLifeDescription: School life follows the IB learner profile framework with inquiry-based learning across all year groups. Students participate in service projects and co-curricular activities. The school serves the Bekasi international community.
sekolah-victory-plus.intelligenceSummary:
Parents say Sekolah Victory Plus is the go-to option for families in the Bekasi area who want IB credentials at a fraction of what the big Jakarta schools charge. The full IB continuum - PYP, MYP, and Diploma - means children can stay from early years right through to graduation without changing schools.

The word among families is that the inquiry-based approach is genuine and teachers are committed, but the facilities are more modest than purpose-built campuses in South Jakarta. The Bekasi location is a real factor - it works well for families living nearby but adds a long commute from Central or South Jakarta.

For families who prioritise IB education and are based in East Jakarta or Bekasi, this is a strong value option. Those expecting the campus scale and resources of premium schools should adjust expectations accordingly.

penabur-international-school.name: Penabur International School
penabur-international-school.addressFull: Jl. Boulevard Bukit Gading Raya Blok A5-A8, Kelapa Gading, Jakarta Utara 14240, Indonesia
penabur-international-school.nationalitiesDescription: Predominantly Indonesian with some international students from across Asia.
penabur-international-school.studentBodyDescription: Penabur International School is the international arm of BPK Penabur, one of Indonesia's largest and most established Christian education groups. The student body is predominantly Indonesian, with families choosing the international programme for Cambridge qualifications and English-medium instruction. The Kelapa Gading campus also has a Tanjung Duren campus for secondary students.
penabur-international-school.academicDescription: Penabur International School follows the Cambridge Assessment International Education pathway through IGCSE and A Level. The school benefits from the broader BPK Penabur education group's resources and reputation. Strong emphasis on academic achievement with structured teaching. English is the primary medium of instruction.
penabur-international-school.facilities: Science laboratories | Library | IT labs | Basketball courts | Sports hall | Auditorium | Canteen | Music rooms
penabur-international-school.schoolLifeDescription: Penabur International benefits from the wider BPK Penabur network, which operates hundreds of schools across Indonesia. The school culture emphasises academic discipline, Christian values, and community involvement. Co-curricular activities include sports, arts, and academic competitions. The Kelapa Gading location serves North Jakarta families.
penabur-international-school.intelligenceSummary:
Penabur International is the Cambridge-stream arm of BPK Penabur, one of Indonesia's largest and most respected Christian education groups. It's a different proposition from the national curriculum Penabur schools - this is a full Cambridge programme through IGCSE and A Level.

The school is well-regarded among Indonesian families seeking Cambridge qualifications with the structure and discipline associated with the Penabur brand. Fees are not publicly disclosed - families should contact the school directly for current pricing.

For expat families, the school is less well-known, but the BPK Penabur backing means strong infrastructure and resources. The Kelapa Gading campus is convenient for North Jakarta families. Less international diversity than schools like JIS, but strong academic structure.
